Award.AwardTitle: Impact of Nonlinear Barotropic Tides in the North Pacific
Award.AbstractNarration:
The daily surface tides in the ocean, forced by gravitational perturbations arising from the motions of Earth and its Moon, exert a profound influence on the biology, chemistry, geology and circulation in both pelagic and coastal environments. As more accurate models of the tides have been developed, it has been realized that non-linear interactions among the tides in the shallow seas and continental shelves (which are all forced by the pelagic tides) result in a flow of energy back into the open ocean, but at altered frequencies and wavelengths. The impact of this energy flux can have significant consequences not only for modeling the diurnal and semi-diurnal tides themselves, but for the energetics of phenomena dependent on the tides such as abyssal mixing. This study explores two lines of research. The first is to determine how much the coastal non-linear tides "contaminate" what is generally considered to be the linear diurnal and semi-diurnal tides in the pelagic ocean. The second addresses the question of whether the flux of coastal nonlinear tide energy dominates the entire suite of surface gravity wave motions in the pelagic ocean at periods shorter than the tides, even as short as 15 minutes, a possibility that has ramifications both for the ocean's energy budget and other geophysical phenomena (e.g., Earth's "seismic hum"; fragmentation of ice shelves) that are now known to depend on these waves. The project involves training of one graduate student.

The broad objectives of this study are to elucidate, using observational tools, (i) the nature (e.g., amplitude, structure) of the pelagic, barotropic, nonlinear tides, especially within the diurnal and semi-diurnal tide bands; (ii) the specific source locations for the energy in the pelagic, barotropic, nonlinear tides; (iii) the flow of energy from the principal, linear barotropic tides to gravity waves in other frequency bands; (iv) the nature (e.g., isotropic or not) and sources of the gravity wave energy at periods of 15 minutes to 2 hrs. These objectives will be accomplished by analyses of existing long (> 1 year) bottom pressure records in the North Pacific that well observe these waves and tides. The methodologies include least squares harmonic analysis and a variety of auto- and cross-spectral techniques, some borrowed from seismology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work was motivated by the need for more accurate global tide models, a need that is echoed throughout the literature. Better accuracy is required for the proper exploitation of satellite measurements of sea height and gravity, for driving high-resolution models of the tides along the continental coasts and in shallow seas, and for driving models of the conversion of surface tide energy into internal tide energy, which powers much of the turbulence maintaining the abyssal stratification. Improved accuracy of the pelagic tides is also a high priority for studies of the solid earth. For example, simulation of Earth’s elastic properties is accomplished by measuring Earth’s spatial response to tidal loading. Measurement of the response has improved dramatically with the use of satellite GPS, yielding as good as 1 millimeter accuracy of land surface tidal displacements, an accuracy far better than current ocean tide models. Improved ocean tide models will yield improvements of the determinations of Earth’s density and elastic structures in the crust and upper few hundred km of the mantle. 

     The daily ebb and flow of the ocean’s tides is the result of the superposition of numerous sea surface gravity waves** at slightly different periods. While the gravitational perturbations at Earth’s surface due to the moon and Sun are well known, the complex fluid dynamics of the ocean introduce spatial structures in the tides that have defied exact calculation. This project explored idiosyncrasies in the amplitudes of tidal components in the North Pacific Ocean. It was deduced that these amplitude idiosyncrasies in the pelagic ocean resulted from a secondary, non-gravitational source of tidal energy; that is, from gravity waves forced at the coasts by the hydrodynamic amplification of the tides there. Especially, the coasts around the Gulf of Alaska appear to be a strong source for waves that alter the expected rhythmic amplitudes of the daily pelagic tides. Having now identified a new process that alters the expected pelagic tide structures, additional work is needed to determine whether this process can be modeled well enough to improve the accuracy of global tide models. 

     The amplified coastal tides also produce a cascade of energy to shorter period gravity waves called infragravity waves (2-120 minute periods) at the coast. This project determined that some of this tide-generated infragravity energy escapes into the pelagic ocean. As well, and unexpectedly, evidence was found that some of Sun’s modes of oscillation (called p-modes) force pelagic infragravity waves via interaction of the solar wind with Earth’s magnetic field that then vibrates Earth. The combined evidence for two new sources of pelagic infragravity wave energy alters our understanding of the energy flow through the infragravity waves, with consequences for at least the following:

(i) how much power is available for deep ocean mixing and where it is located and how it will vary in time; 

(ii) where and how oscillations of Earth at periods longer than half a minute (called the “seismic hum”) are generated (knowledge of the structure of the hum oscillations is an important tool for discriminating deep composition characteristics in Earth models); and,

(iii) how easily the infragravity waves can be modeled as a removable "noise" for the upcoming NASA Surface Water and Ocean Topography (SWOT) satellite mission (possibly easier now than under the conventional wisdom that the infragravity waves are the stochastic product of short-period, 5-25 sec, swell waves interacting with coastlines).

 

** N.b., the “gravity waves” discussed here are the waves that exist in the ocean due to the force of gravity acting on the water. They are not the “gravitational waves” that are disturbances in the curvature of space-time. The ocean’s tidal gravity waves are primarily forced by perturbations in the force of gravity at the surface of Earth, which perturbations arise from the constantly changing Earth-moon and Sun-Earth distances.
